1114761557257244672.text:
9/ Strong sense of collaboration.

@hashed_official, Blockcrafters, are working tirelessly to bring founders to Korea and connecting an insulated market (due to capital controls) with the wider world.

1114761555474767872.text:
8/ In my few conversations with local players, tribalism seems less severe.

People seem more open to projects that are often dismissed elsewhere - perhaps stemming from a focus on practicality (what works) rather than ideology, and that requires experimentation.

1114761552853254144.text:
7/ Community is strong.

I’ve always loved the emphasis on fraternity from my Korean peers, and the mentality permeates the crypto ecosystem there.

Nonce, a crypto coliving space with 50 builders, is a block away from major exchanges and crypto accelerators in Gangnam.

1114761551104200704.text:
6/ Regulators are still hesitant.

2017’s excesses stigmatized the word “crypto” for Korean regulators. There are a few maverick governors and private sector parties actively trying to change minds.

There was a proposal to turn Jeju Island (Korea’s “Hawaii”) into a crypto hub!

The perils of anonymous financing (as @Nouriel described) and the benefits of financial privacy (that @VitalikButerin argued for) is the most under-discussed area in crypto imho.

Enabling terrorist financing vs. maintaining digital privacy is not an easy debate.

1113626463024996352.text:
15/ Nouriel: no central bank will ever hold crypto

Vitalik: CBs already hold gold, not too far fetched for crypto. Tangent: CB issued crypto is interesting but surveillance will be a problem.

1113626459648679936.text: 14/ Vitalik: over time volatility will decrease somewhat but I don’t advocate for BTC or ETH to become a unit of account for the world. Things like @MakerDAO have potential. But value of most of crypto in short term is not to replace global fiat.

1113626455907266561.text: 13/ Vitalik: USD against CPI has decreased by 90+% in past 100 years. Inflation in US is not why people are interested in crypto. Part of the allure is political diversification.

1113626452522442752.text: 12/ Nouriel: People worry the Fed is doing 4x QE. In crypto we have 1000x. Every day we have a new shitcoin, most of which have lost 90% in value. What took the Fed 100 years to do took Vitalik 1 year.

1113626449242550272.text: 11/ Vitalik: most shitcoins with 1-2M mcap will keep on decreasing. Bar for cryptoasset that maintains value will keep rising - but we’re likely to have multiple cryptocurrencies

1113626445635391489.text: 10/ Nouriel: I’ll believe it when I see it

1113626442338684929.text: 9/ Vitalik: Ethereum 2.0 has a tesnet and @cosmos just launched; PoS is not a pipe dream. Many techniques to make validation more efficient are being developed

1113626439180414976.text: 8/ Vitalik: sharding can increase decentralization AND scalability. some genuine concerns but we’re early. Usability wise we will get parity with traditional finance in a few years. Eg @UniswapExchange changed the game with decentralized exchanges

1113626435791417344.text: 7/ Nouriel: crypto is not scalable. TPS is low. Massive centralization among miners. Among developers. Worse for PoS. Vitalik is a benevolent dictator for life!  (Some BSV shill behind me cheers loudly lol)

1113626432553402368.text: 6/ Vitalik: people get caught for tax evasion not because they’re not anonymous. Anonymity is not mutually exclusive with finance. You can have private AND compliant finance

1113626427998392320.text: 5/ Nouriel: human trafficking, terrorist financing etc provide strong incentives for govs to prevent anonymous finance to occur. No legitimate gov will accept crypto

1113626424554844160.text: 4/ Vitalik: story of control vs people trying to break them is much bigger than the Internet and cryptography. Privacy offline will get harder; privacy online may get easier (eg with zero knowledge proofs)

1113626418640900099.text: 3/ Nouriel: regulators with KYC will render censorship resistance and anonymity moot in crypto

1113626415121833989.text: 2/ Vitalik: censorship resistance, makes it easier for people to gain access to finance, eventually more general dapps and more use cases

1113626411732832256.text: 1/ Nouriel: centralization with miners, high fees, volatile, Bitcoin is a joke

1110504933386706944.text:
4/ While it'd be cool to have a tool that quantifies the person's bias, this plugin says more about the people following the account.

e.g. A high ETH score = that most attention given to the person's tweets are from those who engage the most with ETH

1110504931314659328.text: 3/ For instance, this score means most people who interact with @bgarlinghouse also engage actively with Ripple accounts.pic.twitter.com/3qc1eZvICp

3/ Liquidity premium refers to the additional required rate of return for an asset that has a longer maturity/ is less liquid compared to an otherwise identical asset.

It does not imply that by making something into tradable bits/tokens, 1 + 1 suddenly = 3.

1081177487630000129.text: 9/ There's too few data pts to call any of the above confirmed "trends", but what we know is this: sell offs happen in sentiment-driven cycles, each sell off is not as bad as the last, and that out of the 2 most accessible altcoin onramps, BTC outperformed ETH as a store of value

1081177485411115012.text: 8/ Overall, sell spikes are subsiding in scale over 2018. While this seems obvious, remember that there's no theoretic limit to how many times alt coins can lose 70% of their value (besides the smallest unit that exchanges support), especially given current price levels.pic.twitter.com/81tZk6p7tI

1081177483351707648.text: 7/ Comparing price during sell cycles for BTC and ETH gives us a better view. While the entire market rebounded post the 1st cycle, in the 2nd cycle, BTC price held up better than ETH. This signals that the market is viewing BTC as a better store of value during sell offs.pic.twitter.com/yGlJnt0IeJ

1081177481053261825.text: 6/ Leading into every sell cycle, BTC dominance gains and ETH falls. In the second cycle where more than 50% of alts shed most of their value (again), BTC dominance grows throughout the entire cycle as ETH continues to lose dominance.pic.twitter.com/MadcUXbCHH

1081177479513960450.text: 5/ Looking at these spikes gives us an opportunity to look at how differently the market views "blue chip" assets like BTC and ETH in a sell off scenario where fear is the prevailing sentiment.

1081177477114810370.text: 4/ These sell offs are cyclical, and spikes happen as fast as they disappear. Just as FOMO buys lead to the symmetrical spikes in % of coins gaining 200% in value (as @BMBernstein noted), panic sells lead to sudden spikes in coins shedding most of their value.pic.twitter.com/dFuaxEIIjC

1081177474942128129.text: 3/ While there was consistent selling pressure throughout 2018, most of the significant market dips were caused by sudden and extreme spikes in sell offs, where up to roughly 70% of cryptoassets in the top 200 market cap lost most (>=70%) of their value within 90 days.pic.twitter.com/EXJYwW9Sbk

1081177472081645569.text: 2/ In 2018, total market cap of crypto declined more than 80%. Comparing S&P 500 to crypto is comparing apples to rotten oranges, but for the sake of reference: the worst performing decile of S&P500 large caps declined by 43% and mid caps by 50% in the same period.pic.twitter.com/JgG9xpGeot

1075735338142691329.text:
8/ However, @tstyle11 thinks decentralized exchanges can do one thing that centralized exchange APIs cannot - interact directly with contracts.

Contract fillable liquidity can be an edge for dex's. But with tokenized short/leveraged positions, will this continue to be an edge?

1075735336385462274.text:
7/ But a wider question is: regardless of what protocol they use, can dex's compete meaningfully with centralized exchanges volume-wise in the long term?

@QWQiao kindly shared why he's skeptical - the biggest reason of them all: latency.https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/skeptics-take-on-decentralized-exchanges-qiao-wang/id1350649166?i=1000424337920&mt=2 …

1075735334829215744.text: 6/ Users who hold HOT token will see discount on fees (without needing to pay in HOT tokens), and market makers will be rewarded in periodic HOT token payouts pro rata to amount they hold. More details pending.

1075735333407318016.text:
5/ DDEX team will be vertically expanding @protocol_hydro, which was once a liquidity incentivization layer, to include an order execution layer as well.

This will include new ways of pooling liquidity - drawing inspiration from @ShapeShift_io's model and @0xProject's TEC.

1075735331922563073.text: 4/ Side note - I deeply admire @willwarren89 and the @0xProject team, and they are hard at work building governance mechanisms for ZRX (see Will's devcon talk); DDEX simply has a different philosophy that's interesting to explore.

1075735329947082752.text:
3/ ZRX's token also leads to friction.

Requiring traders to buy ZRX to pay for fees is hard. Less than 25% of 0x volume is traded on dex's that require ZRX for fees, and some DeFi projects are acutely aware of this. @AntonioMJuliano explains:https://twitter.com/AntonioMJuliano/status/1070772112397238272 …

1075735328277770240.text:
3/ User stickiness is lower in dex's compared to centralized exchanges. 

The only strong moat for dex's is liquidity. Dex's doing large volumes (DDEX) will not want to open this up for competitors to grab, especially when it's easy for users to move from one dex to the other.

1075735326440677376.text:
2/ 0x's open order books leads to problematic liquidity.

According to Tian, only 2 (out of 13) 0x relayers use the matching model to match trades. Majority of relayers use open order book - which opens up liquidity for others, but also results in high trade collision (20%).

1075735323575906304.text:
1/ DDEX was often the largest relayer on @0xProject in terms of volume.

Problematic liquidity and token friction were the main reasons why DDEX decided to leave 0x and roll their own smart contracts by expanding @protocol_hydro. Let's break them down:

https://0xtracker.com/relayers
